posts.name: Tolga Erdem
posts.cooked: I read on the internet that grease has different uses depending on its color. Does the color of grease matter for FRC robots? If it matters, what color grease does your team use?

Unsure of the answer to your color question, but the thread linked here is really good for selecting grease for various uses.

Swerve Drive Question Technical

posts.name: FrankJ
posts.cooked: The color of the grease really doesn‚Äôt mean anything specific. Best practice is not to mix greases because some of the components might be incompatible. In that sense you shouldn‚Äôt mix colors or at least make sure the bases are the same. Two fairly common greases in FRC applications are red and white lithium grease use base, but white lithium has zinc oxide added. They have slightly different use cases.

posts.cooked: The red taste better in my experience.

posts.name: Chris Bale
posts.cooked:
togicmnp:

I read on the internet that grease has different uses depending on its color. Does the color of grease matter for FRC robots? If it matters, what color grease does your team use?

Jokes aside, if we‚Äôre talking about common greases used in FRC , there‚Äôs a few different answers here.

White Lithium grease is probably the most common, and offers a decent balance of lubrication ‚Äúslickness‚Äù and stickyness (to allow it to stay on gears). If you‚Äôre not sure what to use, this is generally a safe option.

Red Tacky grease is also a good option, very similar to White Lithium but, as the name implies, it‚Äôs a bit stickier so it stays on gears a bit better. Personally I prefer this for our gearboxes, though it can increase friction somewhat compared to White Lithium, you generally don‚Äôt have to reapply it as often.

Aside from those two main ones, you also have:

Teflon ‚ÄúChain Saver‚Äù lubricant which is useful for both chains, as well as gears when you‚Äôre using them in places where grease is impractical (because it would be thrown off and make a mess, typically in open gearboxes). It‚Äôs less effective and has to be re-applied more often, but still better than nothing and doesn‚Äôt make a mess after it dries. Color-wise, it goes on clear and drys a yellowish-white.

Various oil-based lubricants (usually as clear liquids or near-liquids) are also sometimes pre-applied to certain components frequently used in FRC like bearings or pre-assembled gearboxes. These usually don‚Äôt require maintenance (or rather, it may not even be possible), but when it is needed, the remaining oil can usually just be cleaned off and replaced with white lithium grease, or whatever is recommended by the manufacturer.

So to answer (what I‚Äôm assuming is) your main question ‚Äúdoes it matter what grease you use?‚Äù‚Ä¶ It depends.

posts.cooked: IMO if you‚Äôre using either White or Red grease on a swerve drive, you basically have to have some kind of enclosure for it. I can only imagine the mess it would cause otherwise.

posts.name: JamesCH95
posts.cooked:
Red‚Äôn‚Äôtacky is a lithium-thickened grease just like the generic ‚Äòwhite lithium‚Äô title.

Greases thickened with lithium, clay, Teflon, or others can largely be colored with the same pallet. They can all have different temperature ratings and viscosity grades.

Color doesn‚Äôt mean anything.
